thread.title: More needs to be spent to protect the UK in 'deeply troubling and dark times', MPs say

author: Jonathan Walker
title: More needs to be spent to protect the UK in 'deeply troubling and dark times', MPs say
text:

Labour and Conservative MPs have warned Theresa May the armed forces need more resources to protect the UK in “deeply troubling and dark times”. 
Kevan Jones, a Labour former defence minister, and Anne-Marie Trevelyan, a Conservative MP, both said more funding was needed. 
They spoke in the House of Commons following the Queen’s Speech , in which the Government set out its plans for the next two years. Prime Minister Theresa May (Photo: PA) 
Prime Minister Mrs May has said the UK will meet its commitment to spend 2% of national income on defence. This is a target agreed by all members of NATO, the transatlantic defence treaty including the USA, Canada and a number of European countries. 
But North East MPs said this may not be enough. 
Mr Jones, Labour MP for North Durham, said that “years of squeezed budgets” had damaged the UK’s military capabilities and the army was now smaller than at any time since the early 19th century. Kevan Jones, Labour MP for North Durham (Photo: PA) 
He said: “The Navy faces a manning crisis, and the number of new warships being ordered is at an all-time low. Some of the operations that it should be doing can no longer be done. 
“We are proud of the work done by the Royal Marines for the sake of this country, but the numbers of Royal Marines are to be cut to fill the manning gaps at the Royal Navy.” 
He warned: “The Ministry of Defence faces a multi-billion pound black hole in its budget. If it is not faced up to shortly, it will affect the way in which this country can protect itself.” Members of the army join police officers in Westminster, London (Photo: PA) 
Mr Jones said the UK needed a strong armed forces, saying: “The events of the past few weeks have shown that we live in deeply troubling and dark times, both at home and abroad.” Read More How will the Queen's Speech affect you? We look at the key points 
And concerns were also raised by Mrs Trevelyan, Conservative MP for Berwick-upon-Tweed , who said the 2% spending target may not be enough. 
She told the House of Commons: “I shall be raising questions about whether that 2% is really enough.” Conservative MP for Berwick Anne-Marie Trevelyan 
The MP added: “We can and perhaps should be doing much more to ensure that the Treasury can support the Ministry of Defence in the work it has to do.” 
Mrs Trevelyan said: “If, in this Year of the Navy, we are to ensure that we can afford to build the ships we need to protect our nation’s interests in conflict and in peace, we must be honest about what it will take to do so.” Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now 
Other North East MPs raised a series of concerns about the Government’s plans, and urged the Government to ensure the region was protected as Brexit takes place. 
Chi Onwurah, Labour MP for Newcastle Central, said: “Theresa May is still hell-bent on a destructive hard-right Brexit and further cuts that will destroy jobs and public services in Newcastle and elsewhere.” Chi Onwurah (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
And Catherine McKinnell, Labour MP for Newcastle North, told MPs that the North East must be consulted as talks between the UK and the EU begin. 
She said: “I understand that ad hoc meetings may have taken place, but there is still no commitment from the Government on how they will properly engage with the North East on its priorities for the Brexit negotiations throughout this historic process. 
“Nor is there any clear means or a forum for that to take place.” Like us on Facebook
